posts.name: Oliver | 1986
posts.cooked:
For some reason the right two drive motors of our swerve drive are inverted. I tried inverting the drive motors on the two modules, and this fixed the issue. However this caused them to be going against the other 2 modules when turning.

https://github.com/ImpactTang/Cowtown-2023/tree/experimental (Don‚Äôt mind the other subsystem code, that is still a major work in progress.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
maybe this would help:

early on in team 100 swerve work we tried to make the two ‚Äúsides‚Äù of the robot into mirror images of each other, so that the bevel gears would face inwards.

this led to no end of confusion about what the meaning of ‚Äúinverted‚Äù was.

so now we define ‚Äúzero‚Äù to be ‚Äúbevels to the right‚Äù, so every module is identical, nothing is inverted.

posts.name: Oliver | 1986
posts.cooked: Ok, we were turning our gears in so that will probably help a ton. Thank you

posts.name: Alexander Hamilton
Oliver | 1986
posts.cooked: I was thinking that something like that could be a solution, but I didn‚Äôt know how to implement it. I won‚Äôt be able to test it until Tuesday but thank you!

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: yes 100%, verifying the absolute encoder value of each module (and adjusting the offset if necessary) is part of the pre-match checklist.  these offsets will change if you, say, disassemble the modules for maintenance, depending on what kind of module you‚Äôre using (I think SDS offsets survive disassembly?)
